title: How to Draw a Fortune Cookie

steps.headline: Sketch a cone shape, as seen here.
steps.description: It should be rounded at the bottom, pointed at the top. No need to make it especially detailed or three-dimensional yet--that part will come later.

steps.headline: Make a line sloping down the right side of the cone.
steps.description: At this point it should look a bit like a tent or napkin folded origami-style on your plate.

steps.headline: Outline the shape of the cookie with a neat line.
steps.description: Draw a piece of the cookie sticking out underneath it. This should be a thin layer around the left edge that stops just a bit before the edge of what you've already drawn.

steps.headline: Add a piece of narrow paper sticking out from the cookie.
steps.description: It should overlap the portion you just drew that's underneath. Write a fortune on the piece of paper. Make it whatever you want!

steps.headline: Line the drawing with black ink.
steps.description: Try to make a modular line--passing from a thin line to a thick line and vice versa. This will make your drawing look better and a bit more professional.

steps.headline: Erase the pencil from your drawing and start adding color.
steps.description: Use a flat coloring style (this is a suitable style for beginners), or add more details, such as shades and structure if you're more advanced.

text: Sketch a cone shape, as seen here. It should be rounded at the bottom, pointed at the top. No need to make it especially detailed or three-dimensional yet--that part will come later. Make a line sloping down the right side of the cone. At this point it should look a bit like a tent or napkin folded origami-style on your plate. Outline the shape of the cookie with a neat line. Draw a piece of the cookie sticking out underneath it. This should be a thin layer around the left edge that stops just a bit before the edge of what you've already drawn. Add a piece of narrow paper sticking out from the cookie. It should overlap the portion you just drew that's underneath. Write a fortune on the piece of paper. Make it whatever you want! Line the drawing with black ink. Try to make a modular line--passing from a thin line to a thick line and vice versa. This will make your drawing look better and a bit more professional. Erase the pencil from your drawing and start adding color. Use a flat coloring style (this is a suitable style for beginners), or add more details, such as shades and structure if you're more advanced.
